baseline_groups.claim_summary: Overland trade costs in Sub-Saharan Africa increase with distance: each additional 1000 km adds approximately 12 percentage points to bilateral ad-valorem trade costs, and crossing an international border adds approximately 6.8 pp (Table 5, Col 1).
baseline_groups.notes: Primary baseline is Table 5 Col 1: taubar ~ distance + internatl, OLS with N=413 overland links. Distance coefficient = 0.000119 per km, implying ~12 pp per 1000 km. Cols 2 and 4 use decomposed road-type distances (dmichpav, dmichunp, dmichwat) instead of aggregate distance, so the treatment variable differs but tests the same relationship. Cols 3 and 4 add population controls. The international dummy coefficient (~0.068) is consistently significant across all four columns (p < 0.001).

baseline_groups.claim_summary: International bilateral trade costs are not significantly explained by distance alone but are reduced by free trade agreements (FTA effect ~14 pp reduction, Table 6, Col 5).
baseline_groups.notes: Baseline is Table 6 Col 5 (kitchen-sink specification): taubar ~ distance + language + FTA + corruption + LPI, OLS clustered by country pair, N=135 international overland links. Distance is insignificant (p=0.70) in all 5 columns. The most notable finding is the FTA coefficient in Col 2 (-0.166, p=0.001) and Col 5 (-0.138, p=0.035). The expected sign for distance is positive, but the paper reports and discusses its insignificance for international links.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Port-to-world trade costs are negatively associated with corruption indicators, but the relationship is not statistically significant with only 47 observations (Table A13).
baseline_groups.notes: Baseline is Table A13 Col 1: taubar ~ corrupt2013 + sub500 + hivol + gdppercap2010 + lpicustoms2014, OLS clustered by country, N=47 port-to-world links. Col 2 adds trains variable with N=43. Corruption coefficient is negative as expected (higher corruption = higher costs) but insignificant (p=0.28 to p=0.09). The very small sample limits statistical power.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: The elasticity of substitution (sigma) between grains is approximately 1.5, estimated via OLS with region-grain and country-year fixed effects (Table A7).
baseline_groups.notes: Baseline is OLS with region-grain + country-year FE, clustered by country-grain group, N=463. Coefficient of 0.493 implies sigma = 1 + 0.493 = 1.493. The positive sign indicates grains are substitutes (sigma > 1). Significant at 5% (p=0.024) with both FE sets and cgcode clustering.

baseline_groups.claim_summary: The elasticity of demand for grain (epsilon) is approximately -0.26, estimated via OLS with region fixed effects (Table A7).
baseline_groups.notes: Baseline is OLS with region FE, clustered by region code, N=289. Negative coefficient (-0.256) confirms grain is a normal good with inelastic demand. Highly significant (p < 0.001) with clustering.

global_notes: This paper (Porteous, AER 2019) estimates bilateral trade costs from a dynamic structural model of African agricultural markets and then uses reduced-form OLS to understand the determinants of those structurally-estimated costs. The 70 specifications span 5 baseline groups: (G1) overland trade cost determinants (Table 5, 4 baselines + 33 robustness), (G2) international link trade cost determinants (Table 6, 5 baselines + 13 robustness), (G3) port-to-world trade cost determinants (Table A13, 2 baselines + 4 robustness), (G4) elasticity of substitution (1 baseline + 4 robustness), and (G5) elasticity of demand (1 baseline + 3 robustness). The overland distance-trade cost relationship (G1) is highly robust: 89% of 37 specifications show a positive distance coefficient and 81% are significant at 5%. International link results (G2) are uniformly insignificant for distance but show a significant FTA effect. Port results (G3) lack power with N=47. Demand parameters (G4-G5) are sensitive to fixed effects and IV.
